articles.title: Additional Analysis Climate Crisis Behavior Study
articles.contents:
Contents
Descriptive Statistics
Correlation analysis of continous variables
Correlation of all Climate Crisis model variables, different Knowledge measures and Behavior
Correlation of behavior and behavioral intention
Correlation of all continuous variables with behavior and behavioral intention

Kruskal-Wallis test and Wilcoxon signed-rank test for categorical variables
Gender
Education
Occupation
Income
Dietary Habits (including diet behavior)
Dietary Habits and Diet Behavior
Dietary Habits and Heating Behavior
Dietary Habits and Driving Behavior
Dietary Habits and General Behavior
Dietary Habits (excluding diet behavior)
Car Ownership
Car Ownership (excluding Driving Behavior)
Distance Driven for Business
Distance Driven Privately
Distance Driven Privately and Driving Behavior
Distance Driven Privately and Diet Behavior
Distance Driven Privately and Heating Behavior
Distance Driven Privately and General Behavior
Distance Driven Privately (excluding Driving Behavior)
Knowledge


Descriptive Statistics



For variables where a Cronbach’s alpha \(\geq\) 0.7 could not be attained, we chose the item with the highest item-total correlation or, in case of Internal and External Control Conviction, one of the items based on content.
Correlation analysis of continous variables
As becomes apparent from the descriptive statistics, response data is not normally distributed.
Therefore, we use Spearman’s rank correlation.
Correlation of all Climate Crisis model variables, different Knowledge measures and Behavior



This correlation table contains all variables corresponding to constructs in the model, albeit differently specified (see Descriptive Statistics table).
Further, Knowledge is specified differently: Instead of a pseudo-continuous scale with 1 corresponding to an incorrect answer, 2 to a ‘don’t know’ and 3 to an correct answer, there are counts of how often a respondent answered correctly, incorrectly, or ‘don’t know’.
There is also a Subjective Knowledge variable which is a self-assessment of the amount of a respondent’s climate crisis related knowledge.
Most of the correlations mirror relationships are already expressed in the model.
Additionally, there are the following correlations (\(\rho > 0.3\)) which all are significant at the p < 0.001 level:
Behavior is strongly correlated with Behavioral Intention, moderately correlated with Perceived Self-Efficacy, Perceived Response Efficacy and Personal Moral Norm, and weakly correlated with Perceived Susceptibility, Perceived Severity, Descriptive Norm, and Injunctive Norm.
It is also weakly and negatively correlated with all dimensions of Distrusting Beliefs in Science.
Behavioral Intention is strongly correlated with Perceived Self-Efficacy and Perceived Response Efficacy, moderately correlated with Perceived Susceptibility, Perceived Severity, and Personal Moral Norm, and weakly correlated with Perceived Response Costs, Descriptive Norm, Injunctive Norm, and Subjective Knowledge.
It is also weakly and negatively correlated with all dimensions of Distrusting Beliefs in Science.
All Response Beliefs lower-order constructs are intercorrelated, with the correlation between Perceived Self-Efficacy and Perceived Response Efficacy being strong, and those with Perceived Response Costs being weak.
Perceived Self-Efficacy and Perceived Response Efficacy are (at a minimum) moderately correlated with Perceived Susceptibility, Perceived Severity, Personal Moral Norm, and Descriptive Norm.
The relationship between Perceived Response Efficacy and Personal Moral Norm is strong, and Perceived Response Efficacy is weakly correlated with Subjective Knowledge.
Both Perceived Self-Efficacy and Perceived Response Efficacy are weakly and negatively correlated with all Distrust Beliefs variables.
Perceived Response Costs is weakly correlated with Personal Moral Norm.
Perceived Susceptibility and Perceived Severity are strongly intercorrelated.
Perceived Susceptibility is moderately correlated with Personal Moral Norm, and negatively and moderately correlated with the Distrusting Beliefs variables.
It is weakly correlated with Injunctive Norm and Descriptive Norm.
Perceived Severity on the other hand is strongly correlated with Personal Moral Norm, moderately positively correlated with Descriptive Norm, moderately negatively correlated with the Distrusting Beliefs variables, and weakly correlated with Injunctive Norm and the number of correct answers to Knowledge questions.
All normative variables are moderately intercorrelated.
Additionally, Personal Moral Norm is moderately and negatively correlated with the Distrusting Beliefs variables, and weakly correlated with Subjective Knowledge.
Descriptive Norm is weakly and negative correlated with all Distrusting Beliefs dimensions.
All Distrusting Beliefs variables are strongly intercorrelated.
Subjective Knowledge is weakly positively correlated with the number of correct answers, and negatively correlated with the number of questions respondents did not know an answer to.
Correlation of behavior and behavioral intention



The correlation between Diet, Driving, and General Behavior and Behavioral Intention is strong.
It is weak for Heating Behavior and Behavioral Intention.
Correlation of all continuous variables with behavior and behavioral intention



Next, we focus in on the correlations between all continuous variables and Behavioral Intention as well as Behavior and the different types of Behavior.
Apart from the correlations already discussed, it becomes apparent that correlations differ between the different types of Behavior.
COVID-19 Behavioral Intention and COVID-19 Behavior are both weakly correlated with Climate Crisis Behavioral Intention and Climate Crisis Behavior.
None of the Big Five variables show a substantial (\(\rho > 0.3\)) significant correlation with any type of Behavior or Behavioral Intention, nor do Internal or External Control Conviction
Further, there are no perceptible correlations for age, the household size, or the number of children living in the household.
Kruskal-Wallis test and Wilcoxon signed-rank test for categorical variables
As the data for Behavior is non-parametric, we use the Kruskal Wallis test, the Pairwise Wilcoxon Rank Sum test and the Wilcoxon-Mann-Whitney test to detect group differences.
Gender






There is a significant difference between male and female respondents, but the difference in median and mean values is insubstantial.
Education




There is no significant difference in Behavior for different education levels.
Occupation









There are significant difference for behavior according to occupation.
To further investigate these, a pairwise Wilcoxon Rank Sum Test could only be calculated when excluding the observations for student (school) and in vocational training.
University students report significantly stronger climate protective behavior than respondents who are employed full-time, part-time or report to be not in paid employment.
Income







There is a barely significant difference between some income groups.
Dietary Habits (including diet behavior)





There is a significant difference in climate protective behavior according to the dietary habits respondents report.
As the overall ‘Behavior’ variable also includes a measure of avoiding animal products, this is to be expected.
Dietary Habits and Diet Behavior





There is a strong relationship between the reported diet behavior and the reported diet style.
Dietary Habits and Heating Behavior





But the difference persists, albeit weaker, when considering differences in climate protective heating behavior (i.e., concsiously heating less).
For example, Respondents who report to eat meat every day report significantly less such climate protective behavior than all other groups.
Dietary Habits and Driving Behavior





A similar significant trend can be observed when it comes to driving, or the avoidance thereof to protect the climate.
Respondents who report to eat animal products often seem to be significantly less likely to avoid driving.
Dietary Habits and General Behavior





Dietary Habits (excluding diet behavior)





Similar differences can be observed in general climate protective behavior.
Car Ownership






There is a significant differences in Behavior between respondents who own a car and respondents who don’t.
Again, one of the behavior questions asks for avoiding driving by car, so this is not too surprising.
Car Ownership (excluding Driving Behavior)





This difference vanishes when excluding Driving Behavior.
Distance Driven for Business





There are some significant difference in behavior according to the reported differences driven for business in the last year.
No clear pattern emerges, though.
Distance Driven Privately





Respondents that report they have not driven by car in the last year at all also report overall higher climate protective behavior.
As with dietary climate protective behavior, this is to be expected as the overall climate protective behavior includes driving.
Distance Driven Privately and Driving Behavior





People who report to have not driven at all show significantly higher behavior than all other groups.
Other than that, most other groups are rather similar.
Distance Driven Privately and Diet Behavior




Accordingly, there is no significant difference when it comes to reported diet behavior.
Distance Driven Privately and Heating Behavior




Neither is there for heating behavior.
Distance Driven Privately and General Behavior




There is no difference for general behavior, either.
Distance Driven Privately (excluding Driving Behavior)




Nor is there a difference when excluding driving behavior.
Knowledge
In this section, we examine the relationship between specific questions and Behavior as well as Subjective Knowledge.
Today’s global CO2 concentration in the atmosphere already occurred in the past 650,000 years. Correct answer: False.








Respondents who answer this question correctly show show significantly more behavior than those who do not, though the differences is marginal.
Similarly, there are significant though marginal differences in Subjective Knowledge.
Despite its very low concentration in the atmosphere, nitrous oxide contributes about 6 % to the anthropogenic greenhouse effect, as its effect as a greenhouse gas is 298 times stronger than that of CO2. Correct answer: True.







For this question, there are only significant though marginal differences between Subjective Knowledge.
CO2 usually remains in the atmosphere for between 10 and 20 years. Correct answer: False.







The same is true for this question.
The Earth has been in a phase of rewarming from the Little Ice Age since about 1850, which is roughly the beginning of the Industrial Revolution. Correct answer: True.







Again, there are only significant though marginal differences between Subjective Knowledge.
The ozone hole is one of the major causes of global warming. Correct answer: False.








There are marginal significant differences in both Behavior and Subjective Knowledge.
Large volcanic eruptions significantly amplify global warming. Correct answer: False.







As before, there are significant though marginal differences in Subjective Knowledge.

articles.title: Climate Crisis Iteration 1 Measurement Model Evaluation
articles.contents:
Contents
Model plots
Original Estimate Path Model
Bootstrapped Path Model
Measurement Model Only

Evaluation of the mode A measurement model
Convergent validity
Internal consistency reliability
Discriminant validity
Results of the evaluation of the mode A measurement model

Evaluation of the mode B measurement model
Convergent validity
Collinearity
Significance and relevance
Results of the evaluation of the mode B measurement model

Evaluation of the mode B higher-order constructs
Convergent validity
Collinearity
Significance and relevance
Results of the mode B higher-order constructs evaluation

Results summary

Model plots
Original Estimate Path Model
This is the original estimate path model.



Bootstrapped Path Model
This is the bootstrapped path model.



Measurement Model Only
This is a path model showing only the measurement model components.



Evaluation of the mode A measurement model
Convergent validity
Ideally, outer loadings (l) should be \(\geq\) 0.70. Loadings below 0.40 are unacceptable. AVE should be > 0.50.
Internal consistency reliability
Both Cronbach’s a and composite reliability rc should be \(\geq\) 0.60 and \(\leq\) 0.90. The upper threshold of acceptability is 0.95.
Discriminant validity
Discriminant validity is evaluated using the heterotrait-monotrait ratio (HTMT). The HTMT bootstrap confidence interval should not contain 1.






Results of the evaluation of the mode A measurement model
All indicators and constructs show sufficient convergent validity and discriminant validity.
The HTMT bootstrap CIs include 1 for all the Distrusting Beliefs lower-order constructs.
As they are associated with the same higher-order construct, this is permissible.
All constructs except Personal Moral Norm also show internal consistency reliability, with the composite reliability for Personal Moral Norm being too high.
This means that one indicator should be deleted.



CCPN2 shows the highest intercorrelation with the other indicators and should therefore be deleted. All other mode A indicators can be retained as-is.
Evaluation of the mode B measurement model
Convergent validity
To evaluate convergent validity, a redundancy analysis is conducted. The path coefficient \(\beta\) should be \(\geq\) 0.70 and R² should be \(\geq\) 0.50.





















Reiterating: For sufficient convergent validity, the path coefficient should be \(\geq\) 0.70 and R² should be \(\geq\) 0.50.
Collinearity
The variance inflation factor (VIF) should be < 5, ideally \(\leq\) 3.
Significance and relevance
Indicator weights should be significant (t \(\geq\) 1.65, bootstrapping CI does not include 0). Otherwise, the loading l should be \(\geq\) 0.50. Any positive indicator weight implies relevance.



Results of the evaluation of the mode B measurement model
Convergent validity is insufficient only for all Response Beliefs lower-order constructs as well as for Behavioral Intention..
There are no issues with collinearity as indicated by the VIF.
Except for CCRB8, all weights are significant and relevant.
As further indicator deletion is unlikely to improve convergent validity for Perceived Self-Efficacy, it should be replaced by the single-indicator mode A measure.
Evaluation of the mode B higher-order constructs
Convergent validity
Convergent validity cannot be evaluated.
Collinearity
The variance inflation factor (VIF) should be < 5, ideally \(\leq\) 3.
Significance and relevance
Indicator weights should be significant (t \(\geq\) 1.65, bootstrapping CI does not include 0). Otherwise, the loading l should be \(\geq\) 0.50. Any positive indicator weight implies relevance.



Results of the mode B higher-order constructs evaluation
For the mode B higher-order constructs, there are no issues with collinearity (VIF above 3, but below 5).
The weighst for Distrusting Beliefs Integrity and Injunctive Norm are not significant, but the loadings are sufficiently large.
All other weights are significant and relevant.
The mode B higher-order constructs can be retained as hypothesized.
Results summary
To improve internal consistency reliability of Personal Norm, CCPN2 should be deleted.
Other than that, the mode A measurement model can be retained as-is.
Because there are incorrigible problems with convergent validity for the Response Belief lower-order constructs and Behavioral Intention, four distinct behavior-specific models should be estimated next.
The other mode B higher-order constructs can be retained as-is.

Convergent validity
To evaluate convergent validity, a redundancy analysis is conducted. The path coefficient \(\beta\) should be \(\geq\) 0.70 and R² should be \(\geq\) 0.50.

Significance and relevance
Indicator weights should be significant (t \(\geq\) 1.65, bootstrapping CI does not include 0). Otherwise, the loading l should be \(\geq\) 0.50. Any positive indicator weight implies relevance.



Convergent validity is established for both constructs and there is no collinearity.
The weight of CCIN1 is insignificant on the basis of the bootstrap confidence interval, however, the loadings is sufficiently large.
Results of the evaluation of the mode B measurement model
The mode B measurement model meets all quality criteria and can be retained as-is.
Evaluation of the mode B higher-order constructs
Convergent validity
Convergent validity cannot be evaluated.
Collinearity
The variance inflation factor (VIF) should be < 5, ideally \(\leq\) 3.
Significance and relevance
Indicator weights should be significant (t \(\geq\) 1.65, bootstrapping CI does not include 0). Otherwise, the loading l should be \(\geq\) 0.50. Any positive indicator weight implies relevance.



The VIFs for the Distrusting Beliefs are above 3, but still below 5.
With that, there are no issues with collinearity.
The weight for Perceived Response Costs is non-significant, and the loading is not sufficiently large.
Therefore, it should be removed.
All other weights are significant and relevant.
Results of the mode B higher-order constructs evaluation
Perceived Response Costs has to be removed, otherwise the mode B higher-order constructs can be retained as-is.
Results summary
Perceived Response Costs has to be removed as a lower-order construct.

articles.title: Climate Crisis Iteration 2-a-2 (Diet) 2 Endogeneity Evaluation
articles.contents:
Contents
Test of parametricity
Regression of Response Beliefs on Distrusting Beliefs and Knowledge
Regression of Threat Beliefs on Distrusting Beliefs and Knowledge
Regression of Behavioral Intention on its predictors

The code for the assessment of endogeneity using the Gaussian Copula approach comes from
Hult, G. T. M., J. F. Hair, D. Proksch, M. Sarstedt, A. Pinkwart, & C. M. Ringle (2018).
Addressing Endogeneity in International Marketing Applications of Partial Least Squares Structural Equation Modeling. Journal of International Marketing, 26(3), 1–21. https://doi.org/10.1509/jim.17.0151
Test of parametricity
The Gaussian Copula approach can only be used if the independent variable in question is not normally distributed.
So we first test the distribution of the construct scores.
A significant p value (p < 0.05) for either the Shapiro-Wilk or the Lilliefors test indicates that the data is not normally distributed.






All independent (or endogenous) variables are non-normally distributed.
Therefore, the Gaussian Copula approach can be used for all of them.
Regression of Response Beliefs on Distrusting Beliefs and Knowledge



Neither the Distrusting Beliefs nor the Knowledge copula is significant, indicating that there is no endogeneity in the regression of Response Beliefs on its predictors.
Regression of Threat Beliefs on Distrusting Beliefs and Knowledge



Neither the Distrusting Beliefs nor the Knowledge Copula is significant, indicating that there is no endogeneity in the regression of Threat Beliefs on its predictors.
Regression of Behavioral Intention on its predictors



In looking only at single copulas, none of copulas achieves a significant p-value.
However, when combining multiple copulas, the copula for Response Beliefs achieves a significant p-value in some cases (p < 0.1).
On the other hand, adding the copula decreases the size of the path coefficient.
There is nothing pointing to endogeneity in any of the other predictors.
As the copula cannot be integrated in iterative model improvement, the copula test will be repeated for the final models.

articles.title: Climate Crisis Iteration 2-a-2 (Diet) Nonlinearity Evaluation
articles.contents:
Contents
Test for possible nonlinearity
Test alternate models with quadratic effects
Effect of Response Beliefs on Behavioral Intention

Summary

Test for possible nonlinearity
First, we test for nonlinearity by applying Ramsey’s RESET test for functional form to each partial linear model of the SEM.
As quadratic effects of higher-order constructs cannot (yet) be estimated using PLS-SEM, we also apply the test to the corresponding partial linear models of the proxy SEM without higher order constructs.
If the test statistic is significant, the respective partial regression might be nonlinear.



Using p = 0.05 as a threshold, there are potential nonlinear effects in the partial regression equation for the influence of Response Beliefs on Behavioral Intention.
The same is potentially true for the effects of Distrusting Beliefs and Knowledge on Threat Beliefs, but as Threat Beliefs will be removed from the model because of a lack of effect, these potential effects will not be examined further.
Test alternate models with quadratic effects
To test for nonlinearity, one can model an interaction term of the exogenous construct with itself.
Effect of Response Beliefs on Behavioral Intention



For the alternate model with Response Beliefs as a quadratic influence, the effect size is negligible, as is the t-value.
This points to a linear effect of Response Beliefs on Behavioral Intention.
Summary
Using the available tests, we did not find evidence for a quadratic influence of any of the exogenous variables.

articles.title: Climate Crisis Iteration 2-a-2 (Diet) Structural Model Evaluation
articles.contents:
Contents
Model plots
Collinearity
In-sample predictive power
Effect size
Out-of-sample predictive performance
Significance and relevance of path coefficients
Summary table
Results summary

Model plots
Structural Model Only
This is a path model showing only the structural model components.



Collinearity
Collinearity is assessed using the variance inflation factor (VIF). VIF should be < 5, ideally \(\leq\) 3.



VIF is above 3 for the path from Personal Moral Norm to Behavioral Intention.
But it is not above 5 for any relationships.
In-sample predictive power
In-sample predictive power is assessed using variance explained R². R² \(\geq\) 0.75 indicates substantial in-sample predictive power, R² \(\geq\) 0.5 moderate and R² \(\geq\) 0.25 weak in-sample predictive power. R² \(\leq\) 0.10 indicates a lack of model predictiveness.



R² is below 0.25 for Response Beliefs, but not below 0.1.
The other R² values are above 0.25, indicating weak in-sample predictive power at a minimum.
Effect size
Effect size f2² measures the impact of a predictor construct on an endogenous construct. f² \(\geq\) 0.35 indicates a large effect, f² \(\geq\) 0.15 a medium and f² \(\geq\) 0.02 a small effect.



The effect sizes of Threat Beliefs, Personal Moral Norm, and Subjective Norm on Behavioral Intention, as well as the effect size of Knowledge on Response Beliefs, are below 0.2.
The effect of Knowledge on Threat Beliefs is small.
The effect of Distrusting Beliefs on Response Beliefs is medium.
And the effects of Response Beliefs and Behavioral Intention and of Distrusting Beliefs on Threat Beliefs are large.
Out-of-sample predictive performance
Out-of-sample predictive performance has to be evaluated using a simplified model without HOCs as an approximation as seminr as of now does not support plspredict for HOC.
If the root mean square error (RMSE) or the mean absolute deviation (MAD) of the naive LM model is below the ones for the PLS model, this indicates a lack of predictive performance.
However, a lack of predictive performance does not imply a lack of explanatory power.



Only CCBI1 is predicted better by the model than the LM in terms of both RMSE and MAD.
This indicates low predictive power.
Significance and relevance of path coefficients
Significance is denoted by t-test and p values. A t of \(\geq\) 1.65 signifies significance at the 10 % level, t \(\geq\) 1.96 at the 5 % level and t \(\geq\) 2.57 at the 1 % level.



The path coefficients from Threat Beliefs, Personal Moral Norm, and Subjective Norm to Behavioral Intention are all not significant based on both the t-statistic and the bootstrapping confidence interval.
Summary table



Results summary
The paths from Threat Beliefs, Personal Moral Norm, and Subjective Norm to Behavioral Intention are insignificant and the effect sizes are negligible.
Therefore, those paths can be removed from the model.

Therefore, structural model evaluation can commence.

articles.title: Climate Crisis Iteration 2-a-3 (Diet) Nonlinearity Evaluation
articles.contents:
Contents
Test for possible nonlinearity
Test alternate model with quadratic effects
Effect of Response Beliefs on Behavioral Intention

Summary

Test for possible nonlinearity
First, we test for nonlinearity by applying Ramsey’s RESET test for functional form to each partial linear model of the SEM.
As quadratic effects of higher-order constructs cannot (yet) be estimated using PLS-SEM, we also apply the test to the corresponding partial linear models of the proxy SEM without higher order constructs.
If the test statistic is significant, the respective partial regression might be nonlinear.



Using p = 0.05 as a threshold, there is a potential nonlinear effect in the partial regression equation for the influence of Response Beliefs on Behavioral Intention.
Test alternate model with quadratic effects
To test for nonlinearity, one can model an interaction term of the exogenous construct with itself.
Effect of Response Beliefs on Behavioral Intention



For the alternate model with Response Beliefs as a quadratic influence, the effect size is negligible, as is the t-value.
This points to a linear effect of Response Beliefs on Behavioral Intention.
Summary
We did not find evidence for a quadratic influence of any of the exogenous variables.

articles.title: Climate Crisis Iteration 2-a-3 (Diet) Structural Model Evaluation
articles.contents:
Contents
Model plots
Collinearity
In-sample predictive power
Effect size
Out-of-sample predictive performance
Significance and relevance of path coefficients
Summary table
Results summary
Achieved power

Model plots
Structural Model Only
This is a path model showing only the structural model components.



Collinearity
Collinearity is assessed using the variance inflation factor (VIF). VIF should be < 5, ideally \(\leq\) 3.



The VIF for the path from Response Beliefs to Personal Moral Norm cannot be provided.
The other VIF values are below 3.
In-sample predictive power
In-sample predictive power is assessed using variance explained R². R² \(\geq\) 0.75 indicates substantial in-sample predictive power, R² \(\geq\) 0.5 moderate and R² \(\geq\) 0.25 weak in-sample predictive power. R² \(\leq\) 0.10 indicates a lack of model predictiveness.



R² is below 0.25 for Response Beliefs, but not below 0.1.
R² for Behavioral Intention is above 0.25, indicating weak in-sample predictive power at a minimum.
Effect size
Effect size f2² measures the impact of a predictor construct on an endogenous construct. f² \(\geq\) 0.35 indicates a large effect, f² \(\geq\) 0.15 a medium and f² \(\geq\) 0.02 a small effect.



The effect of Knowledge on Response Beliefs is small.
The effect of Distrusting Beliefs on Response Beliefs is medium.
And the effect of Response Beliefs on Behavioral Intention is large.
Out-of-sample predictive performance
Out-of-sample predictive performance has to be evaluated using a simplified model without HOCs as an approximation as seminr as of now does not support plspredict for HOC.
If the root mean square error (RMSE) or the mean absolute deviation (MAD) of the naive LM model is below the ones for the PLS model, this indicates a lack of predictive performance.
However, a lack of predictive performance does not imply a lack of explanatory power.



Only CCBI1 is predicted better by the model than the LM in terms of both RMSE and MAD.
This indicates low predictive power.
Significance and relevance of path coefficients
Significance is denoted by t-test and p values. A t of \(\geq\) 1.65 signifies significance at the 10 % level, t \(\geq\) 1.96 at the 5 % level and t \(\geq\) 2.57 at the 1 % level.



All path coefficients are significant.
Summary table



Results summary
The path from Knowledge to Response Beliefs has a very small effect, but a significant path coefficient.
Therefore, it can be retained or the model can be compared with another model with knowledge removed.
Achieved power
To calculate the achieved power of our model, we use the inverse square root method described by Kock and Hadaya (2018).


# Achieved sample size
n <- nrow(model$data)
# Significance level
siglevel <- 0.1
# smallest path coefficient
minb <- (min(abs(sumsm$`Path Coefficient Original Estimate`)))
# achieved power given the achieved sample size and provided significance level
acp <- pnorm(sqrt(n-1)*minb-qnorm(1-siglevel))
# manual adjustment if necessary
acp <- acp - 0.01
# test: is the achieved sample size larger than the necessary sample size?
minn <- ceiling(((qnorm(1-siglevel)+qnorm(acp))/minb)^2)
ifelse(n > minn,
      paste0("The achieved power given the achieved sample size of ", n, ", a ", siglevel*100,"% significance level, and the smallest absolute effect size in this model being ", round(minb,3), " is ", round(acp,2), "."),
      "Please manually adjust the calculation."
    )

[1] "The achieved power given the achieved sample size of 430, a 10% significance level, and the smallest absolute effect size in this model being 0.116 is 0.86."

Hult, G. T. M., J. F. Hair, D. Proksch, M. Sarstedt, A. Pinkwart, & C. M. Ringle (2018).
Addressing Endogeneity in International Marketing Applications of Partial Least Squares Structural Equation Modeling. Journal of International Marketing, 26(3), 1–21. https://doi.org/10.1509/jim.17.0151
Test of parametricity
The Gaussian Copula approach can only be used if the independent variable in question is not normally distributed.
So we first test the distribution of the construct scores.
A significant p value (p < 0.05) for either the Shapiro-Wilk or the Lilliefors test indicates that the data is not normally distributed.






All independent (or endogenous) variables are non-normally distributed.
Therefore, the Gaussian Copula approach can be used for all of them.
Regression of Response Beliefs on Distrusting Beliefs and Knowledge



The Distrusting Beliefs is not significant, indicating that there is no endogeneity in the regression of Response Beliefs on its predictor.
Regression of Behavioral Intention on its predictors



The Response Beliefs copula does achieve a significant p-value, however, the inclusion does not increase the path coefficient for Response Beliefs.
Therefore, it will not be included in the model.

The variance inflation factor (VIF) should be < 5, ideally \(\leq\) 3.

Indicator weights should be significant (t \(\geq\) 1.65, bootstrapping CI does not include 0). Otherwise, the loading l should be \(\geq\) 0.50. Any positive indicator weight implies relevance.



The VIFs for the Distrusting Beliefs are above 3, but still below 5.

All other weights are significant and relevant.

All mode B higher-order constructs can be retained as-is.

All measurement model parts meet quality criteria.
Therefore, structural model evaluation can commence.

articles.title: Climate Crisis Iteration 2-b-2 (Heating) Endogeneity Evaluation
articles.contents:
Contents
Test of parametricity
Regression of Response Beliefs on Distrusting Beliefs and Knowledge
Regression of Threat Beliefs on Distrusting Beliefs and Knowledge
Regression of Behavioral Intention on its predictors

The code for the assessment of endogeneity using the Gaussian Copula approach comes from
Hult, G. T. M., J. F. Hair, D. Proksch, M. Sarstedt, A. Pinkwart, & C. M. Ringle (2018).
Addressing Endogeneity in International Marketing Applications of Partial Least Squares Structural Equation Modeling. Journal of International Marketing, 26(3), 1–21. https://doi.org/10.1509/jim.17.0151
Test of parametricity
The Gaussian Copula approach can only be used if the independent variable in question is not normally distributed.
So we first test the distribution of the construct scores.
A significant p value (p < 0.05) for either the Shapiro-Wilk or the Lilliefors test indicates that the data is not normally distributed.






All independent (or endogenous) variables are non-normally distributed.
Therefore, the Gaussian Copula approach can be used for all of them.
Regression of Response Beliefs on Distrusting Beliefs and Knowledge



The Distrusting Beliefs copula is not significant, indicating that there is no endogeneity in the regression of Response Beliefs on its predictors.
Regression of Threat Beliefs on Distrusting Beliefs and Knowledge



Neither the Distrusting Beliefs nor the Knowledge Copula is significant, indicating that there is no endogeneity in the regression of Threat Beliefs on its predictors.
Regression of Behavioral Intention on its predictors



The copula for Descriptive Norm achieves a significant p-value (p < 0.1) both in the model with only the Descriptive Norm copula and in combination with other copulas.
However, the addition of the copula leads to the path coefficient of Descriptive Norm being inverted.
In terms of interpretation, that would imply that Descriptive Norm has a negative influence on Behavioral Intention, which is not theoretically grounded.
Other than that, there is a significant copula for Threat Beliefs in the model with the Descriptive Norm copula.
As the inclusion does not lead to a substantial increase of the path coefficient, this can likely be disregarded.
There is nothing pointing to endogeneity in any of the other predictors.
As the copula cannot be integrated in iterative model improvement, the copula test will be repeated for the final models.

articles.title: Climate Crisis Iteration 2-b-2 (Heating) Nonlinearity Evaluation
articles.contents:
Contents
Test for possible nonlinearity
Test alternate models with quadratic effects
Effect of Knowledge on Response Beliefs

Summary

Test for possible nonlinearity
First, we test for nonlinearity by applying Ramsey’s RESET test for functional form to each partial linear model of the SEM.
As quadratic effects of higher-order constructs cannot (yet) be estimated using PLS-SEM, we also apply the test to the corresponding partial linear models of the proxy SEM without higher order constructs.
If the test statistic is significant, the respective partial regression might be nonlinear.



Using p = 0.05 as a threshold, there are potential nonlinear effects in the partial regression equation for the influence of Knowledge on Response Beliefs.
The same is potentially true for the effects of Distrusting Beliefs and Knowledge on Threat Beliefs.
But as Threat Beliefs itself has to be removed from the model due to a lack of effect on Behavioral intention, only the effect of Knowledge on Response Beliefs will be evaluated.
Test alternate models with quadratic effects
To test for nonlinearity, one can model an interaction term of the exogenous construct with itself.
Effect of Knowledge on Response Beliefs



For the alternate model, Knowledge is specified as a quadratic influence.
Although the correct method would be two-stage, the model could only be estimated using the orthogonal and product-indicator method.
Using this methods, the effect size is above the 0.02 threshold in both cases, and the t-statistic does indicate significance for the orthogonal method.
This points to a potential quadratic effect of Knowledge on Response Beliefs.
However, as this effect is still small, Knowledge will not be excluded in further model iteration.
Summary
Using the available tests, we found some evidence for a quadratic influence of Knowledge on Response Beliefs.
We did not find evidence for a quadratic influence of any of the other exogenous variables.

articles.title: Climate Crisis Iteration 2-b-3 (Heating) Nonlinearity Evaluation
articles.contents:
Contents
Test for possible nonlinearity

Test for possible nonlinearity
First, we test for nonlinearity by applying Ramsey’s RESET test for functional form to each partial linear model of the SEM.
As quadratic effects of higher-order constructs cannot (yet) be estimated using PLS-SEM, we also apply the test to the corresponding partial linear models of the proxy SEM without higher order constructs.
If the test statistic is significant, the respective partial regression might be nonlinear.



Using p = 0.05 as a threshold, there are no potential nonlinear effects.
Therefore, we did not test for a quadratic influence of any of the exogenous variables.

articles.title: Climate Crisis Iteration 2-b-3 (Heating) Structural Model Evaluation
articles.contents:
Contents
Model plots
Collinearity
In-sample predictive power
Effect size
Out-of-sample predictive performance
Significance and relevance of path coefficients
Summary table
Results summary
Achieved power

Model plots
Structural Model Only
This is a path model showing only the structural model components.



Collinearity
Collinearity is assessed using the variance inflation factor (VIF). VIF should be < 5, ideally \(\leq\) 3.



There is no VIF information for the path from Distrusting Beliefs to Response Beliefs as Distrusting Beliefs is the only predictor.
Other than that, all VIF values are below 1.4.
In-sample predictive power
In-sample predictive power is assessed using variance explained R². R² \(\geq\) 0.75 indicates substantial in-sample predictive power, R² \(\geq\) 0.5 moderate and R² \(\geq\) 0.25 weak in-sample predictive power. R² \(\leq\) 0.10 indicates a lack of model predictiveness.



R² is below 0.25 for Response Beliefs, but not below 0.1.
The R² value for Behavioral Intention is above 0.25, indicating weak in-sample predictive power.
Effect size
Effect size f2² measures the impact of a predictor construct on an endogenous construct. f² \(\geq\) 0.35 indicates a large effect, f² \(\geq\) 0.15 a medium and f² \(\geq\) 0.02 a small effect.



All effect sizes are above 0.02.
Out-of-sample predictive performance
Out-of-sample predictive performance has to be evaluated using a simplified model without HOCs as an approximation as seminr as of now does not support plspredict for HOC.
If the root mean square error (RMSE) or the mean absolute deviation (MAD) of the naive LM model is below the ones for the PLS model, this indicates a lack of predictive performance.
However, a lack of predictive performance does not imply a lack of explanatory power.



Only CCBI1 is predicted better by the model than the LM in terms of both RMSE and MAD.
This indicates low predictive power.
Significance and relevance of path coefficients
Significance is denoted by t-test and p values. A t of \(\geq\) 1.65 signifies significance at the 10 % level, t \(\geq\) 1.96 at the 5 % level and t \(\geq\) 2.57 at the 1 % level.



All path coefficients are significant and relevant.
Summary table



Results summary
The structural model can be retained as is.
Achieved power
To calculate the achieved power of our model, we use the inverse square root method described by Kock and Hadaya (2018).


# Achieved sample size
n <- nrow(model$data)
# Significance level
siglevel <- 0.1
# smallest path coefficient
minb <- (min(abs(sumsm$`Path Coefficient Original Estimate`)))
# achieved power given the achieved sample size and provided significance level
acp <- pnorm(sqrt(n-1)*minb-qnorm(1-siglevel))
# manual adjustment if necessary
acp <- acp - 0.01
# test: is the achieved sample size larger than the necessary sample size?
minn <- ceiling(((qnorm(1-siglevel)+qnorm(acp))/minb)^2)
ifelse(n > minn,
      paste0("The achieved power given the achieved sample size of ", n, ", a ", siglevel*100,"% significance level, and the smallest absolute effect size in this model being ", round(minb,3), " is ", round(acp,2), "."),
      "Please manually adjust the calculation."
    )

[1] "The achieved power given the achieved sample size of 430, a 10% significance level, and the smallest absolute effect size in this model being 0.27 is 0.99."

The code for the assessment of endogeneity using the Gaussian Copula approach comes from
Hult, G. T. M., J. F. Hair, D. Proksch, M. Sarstedt, A. Pinkwart, & C. M. Ringle (2018).
Addressing Endogeneity in International Marketing Applications of Partial Least Squares Structural Equation Modeling. Journal of International Marketing, 26(3), 1–21. https://doi.org/10.1509/jim.17.0151
Test of parametricity
The Gaussian Copula approach can only be used if the independent variable in question is not normally distributed.
So we first test the distribution of the construct scores.
A significant p value (p < 0.05) for either the Shapiro-Wilk or the Lilliefors test indicates that the data is not normally distributed.






All independent (or endogenous) variables are non-normally distributed.
Therefore, the Gaussian Copula approach can be used for all of them.
Regression of Response Beliefs on Distrusting Beliefs and Knowledge



Neither the Distrusting Beliefs nor the Knowledge copula is significant, indicating that there is no endogeneity in the regression of Response Beliefs on its predictors.
Regression of Threat Beliefs on Distrusting Beliefs and Knowledge



Neither the Distrusting Beliefs nor the Knowledge Copula is significant, indicating that there is no endogeneity in the regression of Threat Beliefs on its predictors.
Regression of Behavioral Intention on its predictors



None of the copulas is significant in any of the model constellations, pointing to no endogeneity in the relationships between Behavioral Intention and its predictors.

Test for possible nonlinearity

Effect of Distrusting Beliefs on Response Beliefs



The correct approach for estimating a model with Response Belief as a quadratic influence would be two-stage.
Unfortunately, estimation was only possible using the orthogonal and product-indicator methods.
These are therefore used as an approximation.
For the alternate models with Response Beliefs as a quadratic influence, both the the effect size and the t-value are smaller.
This points to a linear effect of Response Beliefs on Behavioral Intention.
Summary
Using the available tests, we did not find evidence for a quadratic influence of any of the exogenous variables.

The code for the assessment of endogeneity using the Gaussian Copula approach comes from
Hult, G. T. M., J. F. Hair, D. Proksch, M. Sarstedt, A. Pinkwart, & C. M. Ringle (2018).
Addressing Endogeneity in International Marketing Applications of Partial Least Squares Structural Equation Modeling. Journal of International Marketing, 26(3), 1–21. https://doi.org/10.1509/jim.17.0151
Test of parametricity
The Gaussian Copula approach can only be used if the independent variable in question is not normally distributed.
So we first test the distribution of the construct scores.
A significant p value (p < 0.05) for either the Shapiro-Wilk or the Lilliefors test indicates that the data is not normally distributed.






All independent (or endogenous) variables are non-normally distributed.
Therefore, the Gaussian Copula approach can be used for all of them.
Regression of Response Beliefs on Distrusting Beliefs



The Distrusting Beliefs copula is not significant, indicating that there is no endogeneity in the regression of Response Beliefs on its predictor.
Regression of Behavioral Intention on its predictors



The Personal Moral Norm copula is significant in all model constellations (p < 0.1).
However, adding the copula leads to a smaller path coefficient.
Other than that, none of the copulas is significant in any of the model constellations, pointing to no endogeneity in the relationships between Behavioral Intention and its predictors.

articles.title: Climate Crisis Iteration 2-d-2 (General) Measurement Model Evaluation
articles.contents:
Contents
Model plots
Original Estimate Path Model
Bootstrapped Path Model
Measurement Model Only

Evaluation of the mode A measurement model
Convergent validity
Internal consistency reliability
Discriminant validity
Results of the evaluation of the mode A measurement model

Evaluation of the mode B measurement model
Convergent validity
Collinearity
Significance and relevance
Results of the evaluation of the mode B measurement model

Evaluation of the mode B higher-order constructs
Convergent validity
Collinearity
Significance and relevance
Results of the mode B higher-order constructs evaluation

Results summary

Model plots
Original Estimate Path Model
This is the original estimate path model.



Bootstrapped Path Model
This is the bootstrapped path model.



Measurement Model Only
This is a path model showing only the measurement model components.



Evaluation of the mode A measurement model
Convergent validity
Ideally, outer loadings (l) should be \(\geq\) 0.70. Loadings below 0.40 are unacceptable. AVE should be > 0.50.
Internal consistency reliability
Both Cronbach’s a and composite reliability rc should be \(\geq\) 0.60 and \(\leq\) 0.90. The upper threshold of acceptability is 0.95.
Discriminant validity
Discriminant validity is evaluated using the heterotrait-monotrait ratio (HTMT). The HTMT bootstrap confidence interval should not contain 1.






As before, the HTMT bootstrap confidence intervals are only problematic for the Distrusting Beliefs lower-order constructs.
All others are below the critical thresholds.
Results of the evaluation of the mode A measurement model
The mode A measurement model meets all quality criteria and can be retained as-is.
Evaluation of the mode B measurement model
Convergent validity
To evaluate convergent validity, a redundancy analysis is conducted. The path coefficient \(\beta\) should be \(\geq\) 0.70 and R² should be \(\geq\) 0.50.









Reiterating: For sufficient convergent validity, the path coefficient should be \(\geq\) 0.70 and R² should be \(\geq\) 0.50.
Collinearity
The variance inflation factor (VIF) should be < 5, ideally \(\leq\) 3.
Significance and relevance
Indicator weights should be significant (t \(\geq\) 1.65, bootstrapping CI does not include 0). Otherwise, the loading l should be \(\geq\) 0.50. Any positive indicator weight implies relevance.



Convergent validity is established for both constructs and there is no collinearity.
The weight of CCIN1 is insignificant on the basis of the bootstrap confidence interval, however, the loading is sufficiently large.
Results of the evaluation of the mode B measurement model
The mode B measurement model meets all quality criteria and can be retained as-is.
Evaluation of the mode B higher-order constructs
Convergent validity
Convergent validity cannot be evaluated.
Collinearity
The variance inflation factor (VIF) should be < 5, ideally \(\leq\) 3.
Significance and relevance
Indicator weights should be significant (t \(\geq\) 1.65, bootstrapping CI does not include 0). Otherwise, the loading l should be \(\geq\) 0.50. Any positive indicator weight implies relevance.



The VIFs for the Distrusting Beliefs are above 3, but still below 5.
The weights for Distrusting Beliefs Integrity and Injunctive Norm are non-significant, but the loadings are sufficiently large.
Therefore they can be retained.
All other weights are significant and relevant.
Results of the mode B higher-order constructs evaluation
All mode B higher-order constructs meet expectations and can be retained.
Results summary
The measurement model can be retained as is.
Structural model evaluation can commence.

articles.title: Climate Crisis Iteration 2-d-2 (General) Structural Model Evaluation
articles.contents:
Contents
Model plots
Collinearity
In-sample predictive power
Effect size
Out-of-sample predictive performance
Significance and relevance of path coefficients
Summary table
Results summary
Achieved power

Model plots
Structural Model Only
This is a path model showing only the structural model components.



Collinearity
Collinearity is assessed using the variance inflation factor (VIF). VIF should be < 5, ideally \(\leq\) 3.



There is no VIF information for the path from Distrusting Beliefs to Response Beliefs, as Distrusting Beliefs is the only predictor.
Other than that, all VIF values are below 3.
In-sample predictive power
In-sample predictive power is assessed using variance explained R². R² \(\geq\) 0.75 indicates substantial in-sample predictive power, R² \(\geq\) 0.5 moderate and R² \(\geq\) 0.25 weak in-sample predictive power. R² \(\leq\) 0.10 indicates a lack of model predictiveness.



All R² values are above 0.25, indicating weak in-sample predictive power at a minimum.
Effect size
Effect size f2² measures the impact of a predictor construct on an endogenous construct. f² \(\geq\) 0.35 indicates a large effect, f² \(\geq\) 0.15 a medium and f² \(\geq\) 0.02 a small effect.



All effects are small at a minimum.
Out-of-sample predictive performance
Out-of-sample predictive performance has to be evaluated using a simplified model without HOCs as an approximation as seminr as of now does not support plspredict for HOC.
If the root mean square error (RMSE) or the mean absolute deviation (MAD) of the naive LM model is below the ones for the PLS model, this indicates a lack of predictive performance.
However, a lack of predictive performance does not imply a lack of explanatory power.



Only CCBI4 is predicted better by the model than the LM in terms of both RMSE and MAD.
This indicates low predictive power.
Significance and relevance of path coefficients
Significance is denoted by t-test and p values. A t of \(\geq\) 1.65 signifies significance at the 10 % level, t \(\geq\) 1.96 at the 5 % level and t \(\geq\) 2.57 at the 1 % level.



All path coefficients are significant and relevant.
Summary table



Results summary
All paths are substantial in terms of both the path coefficients and effect size.
Structural model evaluation for this model is completed.
As there have been no indications of nonlinearity in earlier model iterations, this is not tested again.
Achieved power
To calculate the achieved power of our model, we use the inverse square root method described by Kock and Hadaya (2018).

The achieved power given the achieved sample size of 430, a 10% significance level, and the smallest absolute effect size in this model being 0.238 is 0.99.







Kock, Ned, and Pierre Hadaya. 2018. “Minimum Sample Size Estimation in PLS-SEM: The Inverse Square Root and Gamma-Exponential Methods.” Information Systems Journal 28 (1): 227–61. https://doi.org/10.1111/isj.12131.

articles.title: Applying an integrated model of behaviour change to the climate crisis and the COVID-19 pandemic
articles.description: This website contains supplementary material for our paper comparing correlates of behaviour change in the climate crisiis and the COVID-19 pandemic. Specifically, we detail the process of model evaluation and provide the full results of the additional exploratory data analysis for models and data concerning the climate crisis.
